Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Displacement history of the Pearya terrane, Ellesmere Island - evaluating a strike-slip origin for the Canadian Arctic margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a structural, petrologic and geochronologic study of basement rocks that comprise the Pearya terrane of Ellesmere Island, which forms the northernmost landmass of North America. This tectonic terrane has geologic affinities with continental crust in Svalbard and Greenland. It is postulated that the Pearya terrane is the best example along the Canadian Arctic margin of a crustal fragment that has been displaced by plate tectonic processes. A proposed tectonic model for the origin of the Pearya terrane (the Paleozoic Northwest Passage model) postulates that many exotic or far-travelled geologic terranes that make up the northwestern Cordillera (e.g. Alaska) originated in the Caledonian orogenic belt shared by Greenland and Scandinavia, and subsequently traveled westward on a strike-slip fault to their current location about 400 million years ago. The lack of documentation on the timing and movement sense of the Pearya terrane severely limits understanding of the tectonic evolution of the Arctic margin of North America, leaving room for recent models that claim Pearya was stationary and was not the result of tectonic displacement. This project includes field observations and sample collection from remote southern boundary of the Pearya terrane that will be used to test these models. The project is part of the 2017 Circum-Arctic Structural Events Expedition organized by the German Federal Institute for Geosciences and Natural Resources, who will provide logistical support for the fieldwork. The project will involve international collaboration with scientists from five countries. In addition to the scientific contributions of the project, the study will contribute to training of graduate and undergraduate students in an important science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) discipline, which is important in contributing to the enhanced compatibility of the U.S. workforce. The project will also contribute to broadening of underrepresented groups in STEM. Research results will be shared with the public through lectures and will be published in the peer reviewed scientific literatures and presentations at professional society meetings. Understanding the geological evolution of the North American Arctic margin is critical to informing important scientific, political and economic issues associated with the Arctic region. This award is cofunded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

The ultimate goal of this project is to establish a stratigraphic, structural and metamorphic framework for the evolution of the complex southern boundary of the Pearya terrane. The study entails integrated kinematic, petrochronologic and argon-argon thermochronologic analysis of the crystalline basement and major faults at the southern Pearya terrane margin; and detailed stratigraphic comparison across the terrane boundary through sandstone petrography, detrital zircon uranium-lead and hafnium analysis, and major, trace element and neodymium isotope geochemistry on mudstone. Although the Canadian Arctic margin is often cited as an example of large magnitude terrane translation, little is known about the structures that may have accommodated such profound displacement. The project will evaluate possible strike-slip tectonics in light of structures associated with transpression, which may reconcile the earlier observations of straight contraction. The results of this study will provide critical timing on the age of metamorphism and the early ductile history of the shear zones in order to see through the pervasive overprinting. The principal investigators will also evaluate the stratigraphy of the overlap assemblage in different fault blocks to determine whether it is a single assemblage or, in fact, time correlatives of spatially separate depositional systems. By producing a robust data set tied to the geology, this project will help discriminate among the disparate models that currently exist for the Pearya terrane and the larger tectonic development of the Arctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on studying a poorly understood fault system exposed along the Alaska-Yukon border region, which we refer to herein as the Porcupine fault system. More specifically, we focused on examining sedimentary and volcanic rocks exposed northwest and southeast of the fault system, the former of which belong to a displaced piece of crust called the Arctic Alaska terrane and the latter of which represent classically-defined North American crust. As a part of this project, we attempted to define the origin and reconstruct the displacement history of the Arctic Alaska terrane through integrated stratigraphic, paleontological, geochronological, and geochemical analyses from rocks spanning the Neoproterozoic (ca. 1000–541 million years ago) to Devonian (ca. 419–359 million years ago). In addition, we coupled detailed geological mapping with abundant structural measurements and geochronological/geochemical analyses from samples within the Porcupine fault system in order to understand the displacement history and kinematics of the major faults that are exposed at the surface today. This work was conducted over three separate field seasons (2016-2018) in Alaska and Yukon, Canada, and it involved three graduate and seven undergraduate students from Dartmouth College, as well as one graduate and multiple undergraduate students from the University of Iowa.

 

The primary research outcomes of the work conducted at Dartmouth College in collaboration with researchers at the University of Iowa include:

1) The North Slope subterrane of Arctic Alaska originated on or near the northeastern Arctic margin of North America in proximity to Greenland and Ellesmere Island, Canada. These rocks share remarkable similarities with strata of the Franklinian Basin, and were most likely deposited along the northern passive margin of North American prior to their deformation during the Ordovician–Carboniferous.

 2) The Apoon assemblage of the Arctic Alaska terrane represents a juvenile Ordovician–Devonian(?) island arc complex (Doonerak arc complex) that most likely originated in a similar tectonic setting to the Taconic–Caledonian arc system of northeastern Laurentia and Baltica. This arc complex shares affinities with other terranes within the North American Cordillera, such as the Alexander terrane.

3) The Arctic Alaska terrane was most likely assembled from multiple peri-Laurentian and peri-Baltic crustal fragments outboard of the northeastern margin of Laurentian in the middle Paleozoic, during or prior to translation of terranes across the northern margin of North America.

 

4) The Porcupine fault system juxtaposes polydeformed rocks of the Arctic Alaska terrane with low-grade Mesoproterozoic–Paleozoic rocks of the Yukon block, a distinct component of the northwestern North American continent. This fault system most likely represents a long-lived major crustal boundary that was reactivated multiple times throughout the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic. As a result, it plays a privotal, yet largely underappreciated, role in our understanding of the tectonic development of the circum-Arctic region.

 

This project has provided significant opportunities in training and education for the United States STEM workforce. Dartmouth College personnel supported by the project include one MSc student (Virginia Wala), two PhD students (James Busch and Karol Faehnrich), seven undergraduates (Peter Mamrol, Josh Perez, Caleb Town, Joe Malinowski, Jack Taylor, Charlotte Nutt, and Maxwell Saylor), and one post-undergraduate laboratory technician (Tyler Allen). Collaboration with field and geochronologic research of MSc student Matthew Trembath (University of Iowa) has also been provided by this project, in addition to the support of a PhD student from Johns Hopkins University (Lyle Nelson). The project has also contributed to the development of international collaborations between several academic institutions (Dartmouth College, University of Iowa, McGill University) and two government agencies (Bundesanstalt fur Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe (BGR) and Yukon Geological Survey). In addition, it has supported the installation of a new museum exhibit on Arctic Geology at Dartmouth College, as well as multiple public lectures about Arctic resources and geosciences at both Dartmouth and the University of Iowa. This project has supported the publication of a new Geological Society of America Special Paper volume, over eleven peer-reviewed manuscripts (with more in preparation), twenty public presentations at conferences, and at least six undergraduate senior thesis dissertations. Finally, this project facilitated the organization of three separate dedicated sessions at annual geoscience meetings, and it provided key course material for hundreds of students at Dartmouth College and the University of Iowa.
